outline.text: A New Life in Europe: The Dhnie Family
outline.description:
The story of one Syrian family heading for Europe in search of a better life.
For the last two years, the Dhnie family has been living as refugees in Jordan. In August, the family decided there was no future for them there and little prospect of returning to Syria. They packed up their lives and set off for the EU. Manveen Rana documents the twists and turns of their journey in a series of reports for BBC Radio 4’s The World at One.

outline.text: Letter from America by Alistair Cooke: The Clinton Years (1997-2000)
outline.description: Bill Clinton’s second term was dominated at home by the Monica Lewinsky scandal and the attempt to impeach him, but there were major events abroad with the al-Qaeda attack on US embassies in east Africa and the war in Kosovo. A fascinating social, cultural and political history of American life, through the words of British-American journalist and broadcaster, Alistair Cooke (1908 – 2004).

outline.description: Each week Emma Barnett meets the person at the heart of a news story to find out what really happened and how their life changed overnight.

Historic moments from history told by those who lived through them.
A weekly podcast from BBC Radio 5 live featuring the latest rugby news, analysis and interview. With contributions from Dave Woods, George Riley, Stuart Pyke, coaches and players.

The most captivating real life true-crime story you have never heard of - the famous novelist, a body at the bottom of the staircase, a series of extraordinary events and a court case that grabbed the attention of the world. In this unique podcast series BBC Radio 5 live uncovers the incredible story of Kathleen & Michael Peterson.
Kathleen was a successful business woman and head of a multi-national communications company; her husband Michael was a famous novelist. The pair lived an idyllic life with their children in a beautiful mansion in the enclave of Durham, North Carolina. But on the evening of December 9th 2001, everything changed.
BBC Radio 5 live tells the story of what happened that night through exclusive archive material and interviews with those directly involved. In a case that stretches over more 16 years, the twists and turns will shock you; make you question your own beliefs and leave you pondering the ultimate question…what did actually happen on that fateful evening and who was responsible.

Weekly roundtable in which our guests try to answer some of the challenging and controversial questions in modern society. From BBC World Service
Interviews with prominent politicians, writers and artists. The original programme is aired weekly on BBC Persian TV.
BBC Xtra is the flagship daily 2 hour live magazine programme on BBC Arabic, driving social and human interest issues onto the main news agenda of the Arabic Service.
Interviews and discussion with a personal and often humorous touch. With guest presenters plus Kate Monaghan and the Ouch blog team. Ouch is available exclusively online and goes out every week.
Using these short topical modules from the BBC Russian Service, this podcast will help you learn the English language. Updated weekly.
Dramas for English language learners from BBC World Service. Improve your English with retellings of stories classic and new. Each episode is between 6 and 10 minutes long.

Learn and practise useful English language for everyday situations with the BBC. Your weekly instruction manual for saying or doing something in English is published every Thursday.

Essential listening for the broadcast production, journalism and technology communities. Your guide to everything from editorial and craft skills to taking your next step in the industry. Heart and Soul is a weekly half-hour programme that has the scope and understanding to explore different experiences of spirituality from around the world.
Whether examining religious faith or any other belief-system, the programme talks to believers and non-believers, and tries to get beyond superficial notions of spirituality and religion.
Talk back programme where listeners can air their views and put their questions and comments about the network to programme makers, presenters and managers.

Join us as we ricochet through the centuries, bringing Scotland's most colourful characters to life and revealing the historical mysteries hidden within our familiar landscapes. We speak to the people who are challenging our perspectives by making new discoveries about Scotland’s past and give listeners the heads-up on what’s happening historically in their local area.

Gillian Russell introduces a mix of personal stories, kit and app reviews, expert advice and the latest fitness news to help listeners get the best out of their mind and body.

In celebration of the 250th anniversary of Robert Burns - over 300 poems have been recorded by actors from all generations. Visit bbc.co.uk/robertburns for more from Robert Burns.

Sreath de litrichean Gàidhlig a bheir taic do luchd-ionnsachaidh na cànain. Series of letters written in Gaelic to aid people learning the language.
Prògram do luchd-ionnsachaidh na Gàidhlig le Iain Urchardan. John Urquhart guides learners through some of the intricacies of the Gaelic language.
A 5 minute mix from the world's hottest DJs and producers. Lots of tunes in a tiny space, as featured on Annie Mac's show on BBC Radio 1. This download is only available in the UK
All of Scott’s show, without the music! Innuendo Bingo, prank calls, Chris’s stories, listeners’ dilemmas, Real Or No Real, stupid games: it’s all here for you, five days a week.
The best bits from Nick Grimshaw’s BBC Radio 1 Breakfast Show brought to you every week on a Friday featuring the funniest stuff and highlights from our big guests.
Join Radio 1’s resident film buff Ali Plumb as he reviews the latest movies hitting screens and interviews Hollywood’s hottest stars.

outline.text: Greg James – That’s What He Said
outline.description: The best bits of nonsense from BBC Radio 1's The Greg James show every week. Including big name interviews, Star Caller, Ask The Nation and other guff from Greg’s weird head.

The world’s biggest movie stars talk through their best films, with Radio 1’s Film Critic Ali Plumb. Discover how the films they made have changed them, including some never-heard-before stories. You can also watch the interviews on BBC iPlayer.
Get your hands on all the amazing guests plus the best and funniest bits from Matt’s show on BBC Radio 1. Check out the full show every Saturday and Sunday at 10am.

Based on an episode from the new, second series of BBC Three's Life and Death Row, Greg James looks at the story of Daniel Lopez, convicted of killing a policeman during a high speed chase in Texas in 2009.
All the news you need to know from the UK and around the world, brought to you by BBC Radio 1's dedicated team of journalists.
A journey through the finest bits of Lauren’s weekday morning show from BBC 6 Music. A cast of colourful characters, epic tunes and genuinely great guests awaits.
The best of Radcliffe and Maconie; Intelligent music, conversation and a variety of guests. From BBC 6 Music
BBC Radio 6 Music's free weekly mixtape: an hour of fresh new tunes from BBC Introducing, handpicked by Tom Robinson each week in the early hours of Monday morning
In our occasional Screen 6 Specials, Edith Bowman speaks to some of the most celebrated figures from the world of film about the music that inspires them. From BBC 6 Music
In honour of one of Britain's most iconic broadcasters, 6 Music presents this annual discussion on music and music-related media.
Highlights from Adam Buxton and Joe Cornish's show at the Big British Castle, as broadcast on BBC 6 Music.
Robert Elms brings you the latest queries, notes and best bits from his BBC London show over the past seven days.
Discussing the light and shade of life in the capital with Vanessa Feltz - weekdays from 7am.
Life on the water - leisure, business and sport. The H20 show meets the people who live, work or play on the water. From BBC Radio Solent.
A weekly round-up of the non-league football scene across the Solent region

Jack Dearden and Trevor Hunt chew over the big issues of the week in the 13-a-side game, with top guests and a preview of the weekend's action. And you can take part too by calling 0161 228 2255, e-mailing manchestersports@bbc.co.uk or texting 81333 (start your message with MANC).

Jimmy Wagg brings you all the latest gossip from Manchester City. Tuesday evening from 6pm to 7pm is the time to air your views too. To contact the team, ring 0161 228 2255, text 81333 MANC, or email at manchestersports@bbc.co.uk. And you can follow us on Facebook or Twitter.
Latest news from the King Power Stadium including highlights from Monday night’s phone-in, in-depth interviews with Foxes’ stars and post-match reaction. From BBC Radio Leicester
Highlights of BBC Radio Leicester's Leicester Tigers coverage including a weekly post-match round-ups and analysis.
A look behind the headlines of the big sport stories from the week.
Showcasing new music in Suffolk, Richard Haugh and Graeme Mac bring you highlights from BBC Suffolk Introducing. Broadcast Saturday at 8pm on BBC Radio Suffolk.
The BBC Introducing on Radio Humberside team presents live sessions, news and views from unsigned, undiscovered and under-the-radar artists.
Weekly gardening advice with Tim Crowther, including top tip, plant and job of the week and back to basics. Solutions to your gardening problems. BBC Radio Leeds
Insight and analysis on Reading Football Club. Interviews with the manager, players and Reading legends plus goal action and previews of the club’s games. From BBC Radio Berkshire
Extended version of the topical panel show, featuring extra content you won't have heard in The News Quiz
Documentary series telling original stories about real lives in Britain today
Psychiatrist Dr Anthony Clare conducts in depth interviews with prominent people from different walks of life.
Our changing relationship with plants over the last 250 years - from tools to exploit, to objects of beauty, to being an essential global resource we have to conserve. Presented by Prof Kathy Willis.

outline.text: An Eye for Pattern: The Letters of Dorothy Hodgkin
outline.description: An intimate portrait of Dorothy Hodgkin, the only British woman to win a Nobel Prize for science, for cracking the chemical structures of penicillin and vitamin B12.
outline.bbcgenres: Factual, Life Stories, Science & Technology, Documentaries

outline.description: Drawing on new research, Peter White presents a history of disability in the 18th and 19th centuries
James Naughtie profiles 60 public figures nominated to mark the diamond jubilee
A chance for listeners to phone in and make their point or comment on sporting matters.

40 of Aesop's best-known fables are brought to life in adaptations for children aged 5 to 9. Each story is five minutes long and read by an all-star cast including Brenda Blethyn, the late Richard Briers, Lindsay Duncan, Richard E Grant, Jane Horrocks, Jonathan Pryce and Alison Steadman.
Join Andy Day for more songs, stories and movement activities for pre-school children. Autumn term downloads begin on 20 September 2016.

Join Ben Faulks for the assembly series for children aged 5 to 7 - including a story, song, a reflection / prayer and opportunities for discussion. Something to Think About can be used to fulfil the statutory requirement for a daily act of Collective Worship in primary schools.
Join Gemma Hunt for the assembly series for children aged 7 to 11 - including a story, a song, reflection / prayer and opportunities for discussion.

Dance programmes for pupils aged 9 - 11. Dance Workshop aims to support non-specialist teachers who have no previous experience of teaching dance or movement. It offers opportunities for your group to explore a wide range movement types, responding to a range of stimuli including music, poetry and story. There are structured opportunities throughout the programmes to move solo, in pairs or in groups and also to appraise the work of the group as a whole. The website also includes separate music files so that you can give polished performances of the dances once you have finished rehearsing them. Dance Workshop is an ideal way to fulfil the dance objectives of the PE curriculum at Key Stage 2.
Movement and dance series for children aged 4 - 6, with Cat Sandion and Justin Fletcher.
Developing music skills for pupils aged 7 - 9 through songs and music activities.
Each programme includes familiar songs, rhymes, stories and sound discrimination games to develop children's phonological awareness and confidence with spoken language.
Support for Modern Foreign Languages aimed primarily at school children at Key Stage 2, aged 9 to 11. Songs, stories and activities covering grammar, vocabulary and punctuation.
Movement and dance programmes for children aged 6 - 8.
Programmes supporting music for pupils aged 9 - 11 including singing and music activities. There are currently four audio series available online - click below for more details.
Maths quizzes for children aged 9 - 11 emphasising mental maths and problem solving.
Encouraging listening skills for pre-school children with fun sound discrimination games.
Age 5 to 9. Explore The Great Fire of London through music, dance and drama activities.

Music resources to support the Key Stage 1 curriculum and other curriculums within the UK. The resources emphasise singing and often have strong cross-curricular links to other subjects, especially Literacy. Programmes are available to download at any time as mp3 files and can be used from a computer or other device. The supporting resources include Teacher's Notes giving guidance on how to use the resources and a range of audio and video resources including the full-vocal and backing track versions of all the songs and also copies of the music as pdf files. It's an ideal resource for delivering the KS1 music curriculum while engaging children with a range of other topics.
Ready-to-use drama resources for children aged 7 to 9 exploring cross-curricular themes.

Kenneth Grahame's classic tale of Mole, Ratty, Badger and Toad abridged in 10 episodes and read by Bernard Cribbins. When the Mole decides he has endured enough spring cleaning to goes to explore the world above ground...
Ten programmes for 5 to 7 year olds exploring aspects of the new Computing curriculum through music, dance and drama.
The classic ghost story by Charles Dickens, abridged in 9 episodes.

outline.text: World War 1 Performance Pack - 'Archie Dobson's War'
outline.description: The 10 programmes to download combine dance, music and drama activities exploring World War 1, which can be combined to stage our play for KS2 pupils called 'Archie Dobson's War'. Full details in the Programme Notes (below).
BBC Radio York look at issues affecting farming and the North Yorkshire countryside.
Mark Drury, Neil Maddison and Rob Law with the latest Boro news; post-match interviews and reaction following all matches.
The latest sport interviews with Teesside sport greats plus Middlesbrough, Hartlepool, Redcar Bears, TJFA, North Riding FA and North Yorkshire South Durham Cricket League.
